utterances: Have you tried your hand at hip-hop yourself?
O'NEAL: You know, me and my brothers used to do that a lot growing up, but it's way out of practice.
But I see the phrasing in jazz improvisation and hip-hop is very similar, because they'll say (singing) dup, dup, da-ba-da, uh, uh, uh, ba-du, dup, dup, da-ga-da, uh, uh, uh.
And then it's (singing) dup, dup, da-ba-da (unintelligible).
It's the same kind of phrasing.
I notice that the last line of your Wikipedia page entry says that you can solve a Rubik's cube.
Most of the time, I don't keep track, just because I just love doing it.
O'NEAL: But the last time I did it, and it was the fastest time, it was 25 seconds.
Harold, I have to test you on your Rubik's cubes skills.
And I have - I actually have one.
I actually have a Rubik's cube right here.
And I am going - and it's all jumbled up.
O'NEAL: You're going to call me on that number, huh?
I'm going to call you on it.
O'NEAL: Now, I'm going to tell you right now, man, like all kinds of different numbers come in all the time.
O'NEAL: And it really just depends on how it's mixed up.
O'NEAL: That sounds like an excuse, right?
We're going to put you on the clock.
I'm going to walk over, hand you this Rubik's cube, and I will tell you when to go.
Do we have the clock ready?
O'NEAL: This is about to be like five minutes, folks.
O'NEAL: You're going to have to cut to commercial.
That's an old Rubik's cube that he's working with, I should say, but he's moving fast.
His fingers are moving fast on that Rubik's cube.
O'NEAL: I should've told you, man, just because it's the fastest time doesn't mean it's the average time.
This is an original one from the '80s.
I could see just - see his fingers moving fast...
O'NEAL: Good thing I took down that post that said I could eat like 1,000 firecrackers.
Good thing you did take that down because, of course, we have a bagful.
